The Supreme Court is set to revisit its ruling upholding key provisions of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) on August 28th. This follows a review petition filed by Congress MP Karti Chidambaram challenging aspects like the reversal of the presumption of innocence for bail and the ED's powerful investigative jurisdiction.
The petitions argue that the stringent bail conditions under PMLA deny accused individuals the chance to present their case effectively, as they lack access to crucial information. They also contest the ED's classification as distinct from "police," highlighting the potential for abuse of power due to its ability to record statements admissible in court without providing a copy of the ECIR to the arrested individual. The court's decision will have significant implications for the balance between effective money laundering prevention and the rights of the accused.

item.title: In water-starved Punjab, why plans for a new irrigation canal have raised concerns
item.description:
Punjab proposes a new 149.53-km irrigation canal, the Malwa canal, estimated to cost Rs 2,300 crore. The canal aims to address water distribution issues in Punjab's southwest.
Currently, high demand for irrigation water during paddy sowing season strains the existing Sirhind Feeder canal, requiring rotation of supplies. The Malwa canal is intended to alleviate this pressure and provide a reliable water source to seven districts, irrigating 2 lakh acres.
The project faces hurdles including funding constraints and technical viability concerns raised by some experts. Environmental clearances and land acquisition processes need to be completed before construction can begin.

item.title: Bill seeks to expand NDMA role, fails to strengthen its status
item.description:
The government has introduced a Bill amending the Disaster Management Act, 2005, aiming to enhance operational efficiency in disaster response.
The Bill proposes expanding the National Disaster Management Authority's (NDMA) role and responsibilities, making it mandatory for states to raise disaster relief forces, and establishing Urban Disaster Management Authorities for major cities.
However, the amendment fails to strengthen NDMA's institutional status, leaving it without a vice-chairperson and limited financial and human resources. Despite acknowledging the increasing global disaster risks, the Bill neglects to empower NDMA with the necessary resources and authority to effectively handle future crises.

item.title: Explained: The debate over GST on health insurance
item.description:
The government's 18% GST on health and life insurance premiums, coupled with rising healthcare costs, has made insurance less affordable. Opposition leaders and insurance agents are calling for a reduction or exemption of GST, arguing that it burdens policyholders and hinders the "Insurance for All by 2047" goal.
While insurance companies cite inflation as a cost driver, they are accused of not passing on potential GST savings to customers. Concerns have been raised about the declining renewal rates of health insurance policies due to frequent premium hikes. The Standing Committee on Finance has recommended rationalizing GST rates on health, term, and micro insurance policies to make them more affordable.

item.title: Who is Tim Walz and why did Kamala Harris pick him as her Vice Presidential candidate?
item.description:
Kamala Harris selected Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as her running mate for the 2024 presidential election. Walz, known for his "straight-talking" approach and focus on working families, brings a Midwestern perspective to the ticket.
His background as a teacher, coach, veteran, and governor appeals to both moderate and progressive voters. Harris emphasizes Walz's commitment to protecting reproductive rights and enacting common-sense gun control measures. The selection aims to balance the ticket and potentially win over crucial swing state voters.

item.title: Before Bangladesh and Sheikh Hasina, how leaders of Sri Lanka and Afghanistan fled amid turmoil
item.description: Days of unrest propelled by widespread protests forced Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina from power, leading her to flee to India, potentially seeking refuge in London. The situation evokes memories of similar turmoil in Sri Lanka and Afghanistan in recent years. In 2022, Sri Lanka faced a severe economic crisis prompting widespread protests known as the “Aragalaya.” This led to the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, who later settled in Thailand. In 2021, the Taliban swiftly captured Afghanistan, resulting in President Ashraf Ghani’s abrupt departure. His actions drew criticism, but he cited a fear for his safety. These events highlight the instability plaguing South Asia as economic woes and public discontent escalate.

item.title: What is Yen carry trade and why did it help trigger a global stock market fall?
item.description: Stock markets globally plummeted recently, driven by a "yen carry trade" reversal. The Bank of Japan (BoJ) had kept interest rates low, encouraging investors to borrow yen and invest in higher-yield markets. However, the BoJ raised rates, weakening the yen and prompting investors to sell off their investments, causing a market sell-off. This signifies a significant shift in global monetary policy, as the BoJ's actions have rippling effects on international markets.

item.title: Meet Nobel Laureate Muhammad Yunus, the chief adviser of Bangladesh’s post-Hasina government
item.description: Muhammad Yunus, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate known for his pioneering work in microfinance, has been appointed chief adviser to Bangladesh's interim government. Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank, faces a history of legal battles with the former government led by Sheikh Hasina. Hasina accused him of various financial improprieties and initiated numerous cases against him, including charges of forgery and money laundering. Yunus denies these allegations and his supporters view the charges as politically motivated. The international community has expressed concern over these legal proceedings, with many prominent figures calling for an end to what they describe as "judicial harassment".

item.title: Why an Indian start-up lobby has filed an antitrust complaint against Google
item.description:
The Alliance of Digital India Foundation (ADIF) has filed a complaint with the Competition Commission of India (CCI) alleging anti-competitive practices by Google. ADIF argues that Google’s dominance in online advertising, coupled with its 97% revenue dependence on this sector, harms competition and Indian businesses.
They criticize Google's ad-ranking system as opaque, claiming it inflates ad prices through trademark bidding practices that benefit Google. ADIF also accuses Google of self-preferencing its own services, hindering competitor access and impacting startups. They express concern over Google's Privacy Sandbox initiative, which they believe will disadvantage non-Google Demand Side Platforms.

item.title: How Noah Lyles won the greatest ever Olympic 100m race in Paris
item.description:
Noah Lyles won the men's 100m gold in a thrilling photo finish at the Paris Olympics. He edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by a mere 0.005 seconds, both clocking a time of 9.78 seconds. This marked the first time in history that all eight finalists in a 100m race achieved sub-10 second times under legal wind conditions.
The tight competition saw Lyles using his experience to dip just slightly ahead of Thompson as they crossed the finish line, with his torso breaking the line first.
The race was incredibly close, initially appearing to be Thompson's victory based on overhead camera views that showed his foot ahead. However, the fully automated photo finish system, which takes into account the athlete's torso crossing the line, ultimately awarded Lyles the win.

item.title: How Sheikh Hasina’s ouster may impact India-Bangladesh trade ties
item.description:
The relationship between India and Bangladesh has significantly improved since 2009, with Bangladesh becoming India's primary trade partner in the subcontinent. Both countries benefit from strong economic ties, with Bangladesh being a major export market for Indian cotton and India being a significant importer of Bangladeshi garments.
Discussions are underway for a potential free trade agreement (FTA) that could further boost trade and investment.
India has also invested heavily in Bangladesh's infrastructure, including rail and port development, enhancing connectivity and accessibility to the Northeast region.
Any disruption to this relationship due to political changes in Bangladesh could negatively impact trade, investment, and regional connectivity.

item.title: Explained: The 50-year-old relationship between India and Sheikh Hasina
item.description:
Sheikh Hasina's recent visit to India follows the army's takeover in Bangladesh. Hasina, daughter of slain Prime Minister Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, found refuge in India after the 1975 assassination, forging deep ties with the Indian leadership.
Her Awami League regime brought stability and economic growth, benefiting from India's support in tackling terrorism and strengthening bilateral ties. Despite concerns over her election legitimacy and crackdowns on opposition, India refrained from criticism, prioritizing strategic interests.
The military coup presents a new challenge for India. It must navigate the changing political landscape, potential fallout from past support, and the risk of renewed unrest and anti-India sentiment. Maintaining security cooperation with the Bangladeshi security establishment is crucial for India's regional stability.

item.title: How India needs to deal with the new Bangladesh: 5 challenges beyond 1971
item.description:
The fall of Sheikh Hasina in Bangladesh presents a major geopolitical challenge for India. While India has a history of supporting Bangladesh, the current situation necessitates a delicate balancing act. Delhi must avoid being overly identified with Hasina, while simultaneously ensuring a peaceful transition to a new government.
India needs to engage with Bangladeshi opposition figures, mitigate the influence of Pakistan, China, and Turkey, and navigate the complexities of Bangladesh's historical divisions. Recognizing the agency of Bangladeshi actors and transcending partition-era pathologies will be crucial for building a stable and enduring relationship. India's response will determine the future trajectory of Indo-Bangladesh relations in a rapidly changing regional landscape.

item.title: Why Hasina’s fall was not a surprise — and what India must prepare for now
item.description:
Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh has resigned amidst widespread protests, forcing her to flee the country. Her government faced growing dissatisfaction due to allegations of rigged elections, suppression of political dissent, and a severe economic crisis, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Hasina's rule, marked by authoritarian tendencies and a crackdown on opposition, alienated many, including young people, who took to the streets demanding change. The situation escalated rapidly, culminating in her resignation and departure. This development poses a significant challenge for India, which had enjoyed strengthened ties with Bangladesh under Hasina's leadership. New Delhi now faces the task of navigating the unstable political landscape and mitigating potential negative impacts on the bilateral relationship.

item.title: Sheikh Hasina, Khaleda Zia, Jamaat-e-Islami: What to know about 5 key figures in Bangladesh politics
item.description:
Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has resigned and fled to India amidst widespread protests against her government. The demonstrations, sparked by student-led agitations over expanded government job quotas for descendants of freedom fighters, reflect a broader discontent with Hasina's 15-year rule.
Opposition parties, including Khaleda Zia's Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), boycotted the January elections, alleging rigging. The BNP, historically a strong force with roots in student politics, has seen its popularity decline.
Amidst the unrest, Hasina's Awami League, which currently holds power, faces scrutiny over its handling of recent elections and alleged crackdowns on political opponents.
Meanwhile, the army has announced the formation of an interim government.

item.title: From killing Mujib in 1975 to ‘taking responsibility’ in 2024: the role of the army in Bangladesh
item.description:
This article details Bangladesh's complex history with military intervention. Following its independence in 1971, the country experienced a series of coups, often fueled by internal army tensions or political instability. The article highlights key events like the assassination of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman in 1975, the subsequent coups led by figures like Ziaur Rahman and Hussain Muhammad Ershad, and the eventual return of parliamentary democracy in 1991.
Despite democratic strides, the army continued to exert influence, culminating in a 2007 coup that led to a military-backed caretaker government. The article concludes with the 2008 elections that saw Sheikh Hasina return to power.

item.title: As Sheikh Hasina flees, what does it mean for India? Six preliminary takeaways from Bangladesh’s crisis
item.description: Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has resigned amid widespread protests over the job quota system. Despite leading Bangladesh through economic growth, Hasina's crackdown on opposition and media created unrest, culminating in her departure for India. This unexpected event marks the end of her 17-year tenure and presents challenges for both Bangladesh and India. India, a close ally of Hasina, faces the delicate task of balancing its support for her while navigating the complexities of the new political landscape in Bangladesh. Concerns arise about potential instability and the rise of anti-India sentiment if the new government adopts a hostile stance. The role of the Bangladesh Army Chief, who will lead an interim government with political parties, will be crucial in determining the country's future direction.

item.title: Markets are down, but there’s no need to panic. Here’s why
item.description:
The Indian Sensex fell sharply by 2.5% on Monday, attributed to global concerns. Experts believe the drop is driven by fears of a US recession, tensions in the Middle East, and an unwinding of carry trade in Japan.
Global markets also witnessed significant declines, with the Nikkei and Kospi Composite indices in Japan and South Korea falling over 12% and 8.8% respectively.
While the Indian economy remains strong, the market's recent surge had pushed valuations to high levels. Experts advise investors against panic selling, recommending a cautious approach and focusing on large-cap investments. They also suggest tempering return expectations for equities in the near future.

item.title: SC rules Delhi L-G can directly nominate Municipal Corporation ‘aldermen’: What was the case?
item.description:
The Supreme Court ruled that the Delhi Lieutenant Governor (L-G) has the authority to nominate aldermen to the Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD) without consulting the Delhi government's Council of Ministers.
The court's decision upheld the L-G's January 2023 nomination of 10 aldermen, stating that the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act explicitly grants this power to the L-G.
This ruling is significant because aldermen play a crucial role in the MCD's functioning, including the selection of the Standing Committee, which is responsible for key administrative functions.

item.title: Supreme Court verdict on sub-classification: How CJI underlined substantive equality
item.description:
The Supreme Court recently ruled on sub-classification of Scheduled Caste (SC) and Scheduled Tribe (ST) quotas, emphasizing the principle of “substantive equality”. This means the law should account for historical injustices and different backgrounds, ensuring benefits reach those most in need.
The Court's interpretation evolved over time. It initially viewed reservations as exceptions to equal opportunity, leading to limitations. However, subsequent rulings, like State of Kerala v. N M Thomas (1975), broadened the scope of reservations, seeing them as a part of ensuring equality of opportunity.
Despite concerns about efficiency, the Court ultimately recognized that reservation is not antithetical to efficient administration. The recent judgment emphasizes that achieving substantive equality requires expanding the scope of reservations, acknowledging that mere merit does not always equate to efficiency.

item.title: RBI policy: Why Monetary Policy Committee is likely to keep repo rate steady
item.description:
The Reserve Bank of India's Monetary Policy Committee is likely to maintain the repo rate at 6.5% for the ninth consecutive policy meeting. Experts predict a 4:2 vote in favor of keeping the rate unchanged, with the MPC continuing its withdrawal of accommodation stance.
Concerns over elevated food inflation, which increased to 8.4% in June, are cited as a key reason for the anticipated decision. While headline inflation edged up to 5.1% in June, the RBI projects it to fall towards 4% in the third quarter, but with potential upside risks due to an uneven monsoon. Experts anticipate maintaining the FY25 real GDP growth forecast at 7.2% and foresee the possibility of a repo rate cut in December 2024 or later, contingent upon favorable inflation trends and economic data.

item.title: What is a Bailey bridge, constructed in Wayanad after landslides?
item.description:
Deadly landslides in Kerala's Wayanad district resulted in over 219 deaths and hundreds missing. The Indian Army, facing difficulties due to constant rain, erected a 190-foot Bailey bridge to access the hard-hit area of Mundakkai village.
Bailey bridges, invented during World War II, are pre-fabricated structures made of light steel panels linked by pins. The modular design allows for quick assembly and dismantlement, making it ideal for disaster relief and wartime use. The bridge's weight-carrying capacity allows for the movement of heavy machinery and personnel, proving crucial in rescue efforts.

item.title: Are deep-sea metals a vital resource or an environmental disaster in the making?
item.description:
Negotiations in Jamaica regarding the potential for deep-sea mining have highlighted deep divisions. While countries like China and Norway push for swift agreement to commence mining operations, others, including Germany, Brazil, and Palau, demand thorough environmental impact assessments before any approval.
Growing international concern has led to 32 countries favoring a suspension or ban on deep-sea mining, a position supported by environmental groups and scientists who warn about the potential for irreversible damage to vulnerable marine ecosystems.
Despite these concerns, The Metals Company, a Canadian startup, plans to apply for a mining license in the coming months. The primary target is manganese nodules, rich in metals crucial for electric vehicle batteries, found in areas of the ocean floor classified as the "common heritage of mankind."
Critics argue that the environmental risks outweigh potential benefits, and that the resources are not necessary for the energy transition. Major companies like SAP, BMW, and Volkswagen have already pledged to avoid using deep-sea mined materials. Norway and Japan are also pushing forward with their own mining plans, facing legal challenges and scientific warnings.

item.title: What is the impact of Ukrainian sanctions on Russian oil flows into the EU?
item.description:
Ukraine's decision to sanction Russian oil company Lukoil has disrupted pipeline crude oil supplies to Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic. While the EU has prohibited seaborne Russian oil imports, these countries have been permitted to continue receiving oil through pipelines due to their geographical dependence. However, Ukraine's move threatens Hungary's energy security, leading to decreased imports but potential electricity price hikes and power cuts if a solution isn't found.
Despite EU efforts to encourage member states to reduce their reliance on Russian gas, Hungary, Slovakia, and Austria remain heavily dependent on Russian gas via pipelines. This dependence could further escalate as Ukraine's transit contract for Russian gas expires in December 2024, potentially cutting off Russian pipeline gas to Europe via Ukraine starting January 2025.

item.title: From Trump rally shooting to Kamala Harris as new candidate, what July meant for the US elections
item.description:
The US political landscape experienced significant shifts in July. Donald Trump survived an assassination attempt and chose Senator J D Vance as his Vice Presidential running mate. President Biden withdrew from the race, paving the way for Vice President Kamala Harris to become the Democratic nominee. Harris's nomination has energized the Democratic party and positioned her as a strong contender against Trump.
As she selects her own Vice Presidential candidate, Harris faces a choice between balancing the ticket with a candidate who contrasts her demographics and political views, or "doubling down" with a like-minded individual. Recent polls indicate a close race between Harris and Trump, with Harris gaining momentum following her nomination. Key decisions in the coming months will shape the US election, including Harris's VP pick and the political messaging employed by both campaigns.

item.title: How a new tech promises to kill weeds in rice and wheat fields, remove need for stubble-burning
item.description:
Agricultural scientists are making strides towards more sustainable rice and wheat farming practices. New rice varieties and wheat hybrids, developed by both public and private sectors, are engineered to tolerate the herbicide Imazethapyr. This allows farmers to effectively control weeds without the need for extensive water usage, field flooding, or plowing, reducing the ecological footprint of these crops.
These "imazethapyr-tolerant" crops represent a significant advancement in sustainable agriculture. Direct-seeded rice and zero-tillage wheat technologies, combined with Imazethapyr, promise water savings, reduced labor costs, and lessened environmental impact.
What's more, these technologies utilize a mutation in the plant's existing ALS gene, eliminating concerns related to genetically modified organisms (GMOs). This approach is expected to encourage wider adoption, leading to more climate-smart and environmentally friendly agricultural practices.

item.title: From pigeon shooting to tug-of-war, 5 sports that are no longer part of the Olympics
item.description:
This article explores five Olympic events that are no longer included in the Games.
Live pigeon shooting, held at the 1900 Paris Olympics, involved competitors killing as many live pigeons as possible. It was later replaced by clay pigeon shooting. Hot air ballooning, a demonstration sport at the 1900 Games, featured various contests over several months. Tug-of-war, contested between 1900 and 1920, was a physical battle of strength. Underwater swimming, also known as "static swimming," required athletes to remain motionless underwater for the greatest distance. Finally, running deer shooting involved hitting a moving target shaped like a deer.

item.title: Russia-US prisoner exchange: How prisoners become pawns in international power politics
item.description:
A recent prisoner swap between Russia and the West saw Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan, both American citizens convicted of espionage, freed in exchange for eight individuals held in European and US prisons. This exchange highlights the complex dynamics of prisoner negotiations, where the price of freedom is often influenced by factors like political pressure, the detainee's profile, and the potential for reciprocal concessions.
Historical examples, from ancient Greece to modern-day, illustrate how prisoners have been used as bargaining chips in international relations. Past swaps, like the Powers-Abel exchange during the Cold War, demonstrate the role of intelligence and strategic motivations in determining prisoner releases.
Critics argue that paying high prices for prisoner releases, as seen in the Zaghari-Ratcliffe case, encourages hostile regimes to engage in similar tactics. The recent swap has also drawn scrutiny for the perceived imbalance in the profiles of those released from each side. Ultimately, the negotiations surrounding prisoner releases involve difficult choices and ethical considerations, with no simple solutions.

item.title: What is special about the flying cauldron in the 2024 Olympics?
item.description:
Inspired by the Montgolfier brothers, the Paris 2024 Olympic cauldron is a 30-meter high hot air balloon design. Created by Mathieu Lehanneur, the cauldron features a seven-meter diameter ring of fire symbolizing fraternity and is set in Jardin des Tuileries, the site of the Montgolfiers' first successful balloon flight in 1783.
The cauldron, illuminated by 40 LED lights and 200 misting nozzles, operates on electricity rather than fossil fuel, reflecting the Games' commitment to sustainability. It is a unique feature for the Olympics, with visitors granted free access to admire and photograph it.

item.title: What is the story of Abhimanyu and the chakravyuh, invoked by Rahul Gandhi in Parliament
item.description: Rahul Gandhi's recent criticism of the Indian budget, likening it to a "lotus-shaped chakravyuh", drew comparisons to the Mahabharata battle strategy. The chakravyuh, a difficult military formation, trapped Abhimanyu, the son of Arjuna, who knew only how to enter it, not exit. Despite his bravery and skill, Abhimanyu was overwhelmed and killed by six Kaurava warriors, highlighting the ethical complexities of war. Gandhi's use of this analogy suggests a critique of a powerful, controlling force that traps and limits individuals, drawing parallels to the historical struggle.

item.title: Paris Olympics: In Imane Khelif vs Angela Carini boxing controversy, why issue of gender took centre stage
item.description:
Imane Khelif, an Algerian boxer, won her Round of 16 match at the Paris Olympics after her opponent, Angela Carini from Italy, withdrew early. Khelif's win sparked controversy and abuse due to speculation about her gender identity and potential biological advantages.
The International Boxing Association (IBA) had previously banned Khelif and another boxer from competing in their World Championship, citing "gender eligibility" issues. However, Khelif and the other athlete are competing at the Olympics because the IBA was derecognised by the International Olympic Committee (IOC). The IOC's eligibility rules for Paris rely solely on an athlete's passport-stated gender.
This case highlights the ongoing debate surrounding transgender athletes' participation in women's sports, particularly concerning testosterone levels and potential competitive advantages. Different sports federations have implemented varying regulations, adding complexity to the issue.

item.title: What is the potential fallout of Israel’s killing of senior Hamas, Hezbollah leaders?
item.description:
A series of targeted assassinations has drastically escalated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israel killed top Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr, Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh, and purported Hamas attack planner Mohammed Deif. This was seen as a victory for Israel, aimed at neutralizing Hamas and demonstrating its resolve after the October 7th attacks.
However, these killings have inflamed tensions in the region, raising the risk of all-out war. Iran, which sponsors both Hezbollah and Hamas, has vowed retaliation. Possible Iranian responses include aerial strikes against Israel, coordinating attacks with its allies, or targeting Israeli officials abroad. These scenarios pose significant security risks for India, including its citizens living in the region and its energy security, as a major portion of its crude oil and natural gas imports come from the West Asian region.

item.title: Paris Olympics boxing gender debate: Why was Imane Khelif allowed to compete against Angela Carini?
item.description:
The Paris Olympics saw controversy after two boxers, Imane Khelif (Algeria) and Lin Yu-ting (Chinese Taipei), were allowed to compete despite failing gender eligibility tests. The International Boxing Association (IBA) had banned them, citing a 'separate and recognized test' which they did not disclose. However, the IOC, which deregistered the IBA due to management and financial disputes, overruled the decision, stating the boxers' passports declared them female.
The IOC allows sports federations to set their own eligibility criteria, as long as they adhere to principles of fairness, inclusion, and no presumption of advantage. Other sports, like athletics and swimming, have implemented specific testosterone limits for transgender athletes. The situation highlights the ongoing debate surrounding transgender athletes' participation in sports.

item.title: Apex court rules states can sub-classify SCs and STs for quota: Tribal and Dalit communities that may be affected
item.description:
The Supreme Court ruling allows states to sub-classify Scheduled Castes for reservation purposes based on varying degrees of social backwardness.
The article examines significant SC and tribal communities in ten Indian states.
In Maharashtra, the Mahar and Matang communities are prominent among SCs, while Gond and Bhil are significant tribal groups. Rajasthan sees Meghwal as the largest SC community, while Meena tribals hold political influence. Odisha has a large Khond tribal population and a diverse SC population dominated by the Pan community. Chhattisgarh's Gond population is substantial, as are its SC communities, with a large group known by various names. Madhya Pradesh sees the larger SC group traditionally engaged in leather work, while Bhil and Gond communities are prominent tribals.
West Bengal has Rajbanshi and Matua communities as the dominant SC groups, while Gujarat's Vankar SC community stands out for its educational and job achievements. Assam's Bodo tribe is politically influential, while Tripura has a significant Tripuri population, and Uttarakhand has Harijan and Balmiki communities as prominent among SCs.

item.title: Explained: Legal challenges to the Great Nicobar infrastructure project
item.description: The Great Nicobar Island (GNI) infrastructure project, a Rs 72,000 crore undertaking involving an airport, transshipment terminal, and township, has faced legal challenges due to concerns about its environmental and social impact. Legal challenges centre on the project's potential damage to biodiversity, inadequate environmental impact studies, and lack of transparency in the clearance process. Organizations and activists argue that the project threatens the island's fragile ecosystem and the rights of indigenous communities. Although a National Green Tribunal (NGT)-appointed high-powered committee found the project's port location outside a prohibited zone, concerns remain about coral conservation and limited data collection. The project also faces scrutiny over its strategic implications, given India's increasing focus on maritime security in the region.

item.title: Why the Odisha government will plant palm trees to combat lightning strikes
item.description: Odisha faces a significant problem with lightning strikes, which have killed over 3,000 people in the last decade. To address this, the government has approved a plan to plant 19 lakh palm trees, aiming to act as lightning conductors. However, experts have raised concerns about the effectiveness of this strategy, highlighting the long time it takes for palm trees to mature and the risk of fire after lightning strikes. They advocate for data-driven solutions and a comprehensive approach that includes public awareness campaigns about lightning safety.

item.title: Sub-classification of SCs, STs: Could OBC model for ‘creamy layer’ be a blueprint?
item.description:
The Supreme Court has permitted the sub-classification of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes to create separate quotas for the most backward within these communities. This decision follows a similar practice for Other Backward Classes (OBCs), where a "creamy layer" exclusion is implemented.
The court acknowledged the need for a specific criteria for identifying the creamy layer within SC and ST communities, though no exact framework was proposed. Justice Pankaj Mithal suggested differentiating between those studying in urban and rural educational institutions as a potential factor.
Implementing this sub-classification will require states to establish committees, similar to the one formed for OBCs, to define the criteria for excluding the creamy layer from reservation benefits.

item.title: Explained: Supreme Court’s verdict on sub-classification of SCs and STs
item.description:
The Supreme Court has ruled that states can sub-classify Scheduled Castes (SC) and Scheduled Tribes (ST) communities to provide wider protections to more backward groups within these categories. This overturns a 2004 decision that deemed SCs and STs as a homogenous group.
The court recognized that there are internal differences within SCs and STs and that states have the power to identify levels of social backwardness. States will need to provide empirical evidence and a reasonable rationale for sub-classifying communities.
Justice Gavai also suggested introducing a 'creamy layer' exception for SCs and STs, similar to the one for Other Backward Classes (OBCs), to ensure that reservations benefit those most in need. However, this opinion was not shared by the majority.

item.title: Use data, reason, don’t split to keep out: How Supreme Court lays down red lines in sub-classification verdict
item.description:
The Supreme Court ruled in favor of allowing sub-classification within Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes quotas, but set strict guidelines. States cannot micro-classify in a way that undermines equality or replaces it with excessive categorization. They must provide "reasonable" grounds based on empirical data and subject to judicial scrutiny.
The ruling uses the example of farm loan waivers to illustrate that states must prove the rationality of any distinctions they make. Justice BR Gavai, in a concurring opinion, advocates for a "creamy layer" framework even for SC/ST quotas to ensure that affirmative action benefits those most in need.

item.title: Russia releases Evan Gershkovich under prisoner swap deal: Why was the Wall Street Journal journalist arrested?
item.description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter detained in Russia since March 2023 on espionage charges, was released in a large prisoner swap between the US and Russia. Gershkovich, who had reported from Moscow before for other news agencies, denied the accusations and his trial was widely criticized as a sham. The swap is part of ongoing negotiations between the two countries, and involves the release of other Americans held in Russia, including former marine Paul Whelan. In exchange, Russia is expected to see the release of its citizens imprisoned in the West.

item.title: SUV driver gets bail in Delhi UPSC aspirants’ death case: What is the charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder?
item.description:
A Delhi court granted bail to businessman Manoj Kathuria, accused in the drowning deaths of three UPSC aspirants at Rau's IAS Study Circle. Kathuria was driving his SUV on a waterlogged road, causing a wave that flooded the basement where the aspirants were trapped.
While initially charged under Section 105 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for culpable homicide not amounting to murder, the Delhi police dropped the charge during his bail hearing. The charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder is invoked in cases where deaths occur due to negligence or inaction, even without premeditation.
Courts have often grappled with this charge, considering whether the accused had knowledge that their actions could lead to death. Previous cases involving building collapses, train accidents, and drunken driving have seen this charge applied, with varying degrees of success in securing convictions.

item.title: Why Madhya Pradesh will begin disposal of toxic waste nearly 40 years after the Bhopal Gas Tragedy
item.description:
Nearly 40 years after the Bhopal gas tragedy, the Madhya Pradesh state government is finally proceeding with the incineration of 337 Metric Tons of toxic waste from the Union Carbide facility. The decision comes after years of delays and opposition, spurred by the need to address environmental pollution and alleviate the suffering of survivors.
The process involves transporting the waste to a disposal site, blending it with reagents, and ultimately incinerating it. The project is estimated to cost Rs 126 crore and take 180 days to complete. While authorities claim the incineration process will be safe and adhere to environmental standards, there are concerns raised by residents and environmental groups regarding potential health risks associated with dioxins and furans released during incineration.

item.title: With Nguyen Phu Trong gone, are EU-Vietnam ties at risk?
item.description:
Vietnam’s new leadership, led by President To Lam, is expected to maintain the country's long-standing policy of balancing relations with major powers. Despite economic growth and strengthened ties with the EU, concerns remain regarding Hanoi's human rights record.
To Lam, a former police chief, lacks extensive foreign policy experience and is associated with a controversial kidnapping incident in Germany. This, coupled with an anticipated increase in human rights violations under his leadership, could lead to increased scrutiny and pressure from the EU.
Analysts suggest the European Union needs to adopt a more critical stance towards Vietnam's human rights abuses, potentially employing targeted sanctions and trade pressure to address the escalating situation.

item.title: Why do landslides occur, and what triggered the tragedy in Wayanad?
item.description:
Landslides are increasingly frequent due to climate change, causing significant casualties and affecting livelihoods globally. India accounts for 8% of global landslide-related deaths.
A new high-resolution landslide susceptibility map developed by IIT-Madras reveals 13.17% of India is vulnerable, with Sikkim and Kerala being the most at-risk. ISRO's "Landslide Atlas of India" also identifies Himalayan and Western Ghats regions as hotspots.
Landslides are triggered by factors like heavy rainfall and human activities, such as deforestation and unsustainable land-use practices. Research suggests that monocropping in Kerala, replacing deep-rooted native trees with shallow-rooted crops, is contributing to landslide vulnerability.

item.title: Supreme Court allows sub-categorisation in Scheduled Caste reservation: What is the case?
item.description:
The Supreme Court has ruled in favor of sub-categorizing Scheduled Castes for reservation purposes, acknowledging the historical and empirical evidence of inequality within this group.
A seven-judge bench overturned a 2004 judgment that classified Scheduled Castes as a homogenous entity, allowing states to provide wider protection to underrepresented castes.
The court acknowledged that the concept of a "creamy layer" within SCs, which limits reservation benefits to those below a certain income threshold, also applies to sub-categorization.
The ruling will significantly impact reservations for marginalized communities in various states, particularly for castes like Balmikis and Mazhabi Sikhs in Punjab, and Madigas in Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: Was the recent Kathmandu plane crash caused by a ‘wing stall’?
item.description:
On July 24th, a Bombardier CRJ200 crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu’s Tribhuvan International Airport, killing all but one passenger.
Analysis of video footage suggests the plane suffered an "unusual attitude," possibly due to a wing stall, leading to a steep right bank. This situation is characterized by excessive tilt beyond normal banking limits, potentially due to a high angle of attack on the wings causing a loss of lift.
Recovery from a stall requires lowering the nose to reduce the angle of attack and regain lift. However, at the low altitude the plane was flying, Captain Shakya likely had insufficient time to recover effectively.

item.title: Explained: The ‘Axis of resistance’, which includes Iran-backed groups like Hamas, Hezbollah
item.description:
Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas leader, was killed in an airstrike in Tehran. Israel, while not officially taking responsibility, is the suspected culprit. Hamas and Iran have accused Israel and vowed retaliation.
Experts predict increased attacks by Israel’s adversaries, who make up the ‘axis of resistance’. This coalition, comprising groups like Hezbollah, Hamas, and the Houthis, was formed to counter US and Israeli influence in the region.
The 'axis of resistance’ emerged after the 1979 Iranian Revolution, driven by Iran’s desire to expand its political and military power and deter threats from Israel and the US.

item.title: Hamas chief assassinated: Why this will rattle the region and worry Delhi
item.description:
Ismail Haniyeh, the head of Hamas’s political bureau, was assassinated in Tehran, marking a significant escalation in the Israel-Hamas war. Israel views this as a victory in its effort to neutralize Hamas, while Hamas considers it a major provocation and a grave escalation.
The assassination took place on Iranian soil, signaling that Israel sees Hamas leaders as targets even outside of Gaza. This act is expected to provoke Iran and potentially lead to further conflict.
The assassination also benefits Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu by potentially delaying a hostage deal and prolonging his grip on power. The US elections are further complicated by the incident, with Vice President Kamala Harris facing pressure to respond to the escalating situation.
The assassination raises concerns for regional stability, with Qatar, Turkey, and Yemen condemning the act. India is carefully considering its response, mindful of the sensitivities involved while prioritizing peace and stability in the region.

item.title: Explained: SEBI’s proposed measures to curb F&O speculation
item.description:
The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has proposed measures to curb speculative trading in index derivatives, particularly among individual investors.
These include increasing the minimum contract size, requiring upfront collection of option premiums, implementing intraday monitoring of position limits, and rationalizing weekly index products. SEBI also suggests removing certain margin benefits, standardizing options strike prices, and increasing margins near contract expiry. These proposals aim to enhance investor protection and promote market stability by addressing concerns about excessive trading volume and potential losses.

item.title: Da Vinci’s Last Supper or a depiction of Greek god Dionysus? Why LGBTQ tableau in Paris has created a storm
item.description:
The Paris Olympics opening ceremony sparked controversy over a tableau featuring drag queens, a transgender model, and a blue-painted singer, which some critics deemed a mockery of Leonardo da Vinci's "The Last Supper." The Catholic church and far-right groups condemned the act as an insult to Christianity.
Organizers denied intending to portray da Vinci's mural, instead claiming inspiration from Dionysus, the Greek god of festivities, and a pagan feast. They asserted the scene conveyed values of love, freedom, and belief. However, others interpreted it as a representation of the Athenian Festival of Dionysus or a reference to Dutch artist Jan van Bijlert's "The Feast of the Gods."

item.title: On the 85th death anniversary of Udham Singh, a look at Punjab govt’s promises to memorialise him
item.description:
Udham Singh, who assassinated the former lieutenant governor of Punjab, Michael O’Dwyer, as revenge for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, is an icon in Punjab.
A memorial was established in his hometown, Sunam, and his remains were repatriated to India in 1974. Though several statues and institutions bear his name, incomplete promises remain. A dedicated space within the memorial for the urns containing his ashes remains unused, and historians advocate for displaying his personal belongings and letters within the memorial. Promises have been made to bring these objects back from London, including his pistol, but tangible action is yet to be taken.

item.title: 8 key takeaways from Hamas chief’s assassination
item.description:
Ismail Haniyeh, the head of Hamas's political bureau, was assassinated in Tehran, marking a significant escalation in the Israel-Hamas conflict. Hamas views the killing as a major provocation, especially as it occurred on Iranian soil.
This event is expected to pressure Iran, potentially leading to further hostilities with Israel. Internally, Hamas and Iran may call for revenge, posing a challenge to Iranian President Pezeshkian's efforts for dialogue with the West.
For Israel, the assassination strengthens Prime Minister Netanyahu's position, potentially prolonging the war in Gaza.
The United States faces a complicated situation, with Democratic Vice President Harris needing to respond to the escalating situation and its potential impact on US foreign policy.
The assassination raises regional concerns, as Qatar, Turkey, and the Houthis have condemned the killing, and other key players like Saudi Arabia and the UAE watch developments closely. The incident could draw the Middle East into a larger conflict.

item.title: Israeli strikes: What is Hezbollah and why are fears over a new regional conflict being raised?
item.description:
Hezbollah mourns the death of Fuad Shukr, its senior military commander, killed in an Israeli airstrike in Beirut. Israel claims Shukr was responsible for recent attacks, including a rocket strike on the Golan Heights that killed 12 children and teenagers.
Hezbollah's role in the recent escalation is significant, as the group has a history of retaliation against Israel and possesses a large arsenal of rockets. Hezbollah's involvement in Lebanese politics adds another layer of complexity, as it is part of the ruling government. Despite concerns over potential wider conflict, there are hopes for de-escalation, with both sides seemingly hesitant to trigger a full-scale war.

item.title: Why River Seine’s water quality poses a challenge for the Paris Olympics
item.description: The swimming leg of the men's triathlon in the Paris Olympics faced postponement due to concerns over water quality in the River Seine. Despite significant investments by Paris to improve the Seine's condition, heavy rains continue to overwhelm the city's aging sewage system, leading to untreated wastewater and high levels of E. coli bacteria in the river. This situation jeopardizes the safety of athletes and violates pollution standards set by the European Union and the World Triathlon Federation. The swimming events, initially scheduled for July 30 and 31, and August 5, are subject to water quality tests and have reserve days planned. If necessary, the events may be canceled or moved to an alternative venue.

item.title: Why investors did not pick up Jammu and Kashmir lithium block in auction
item.description:
The auction for a lithium block in Jammu and Kashmir's Reasi district has been cancelled for the second time due to a lack of investor interest. Despite initially being hailed as one of the world's largest lithium deposits, the block has failed to attract bidders due to concerns surrounding extraction costs, processing complexities, and unclear economic viability. Experts suggest that India's reliance on outdated mineral reporting standards combined with global lithium price fluctuations are deterrents for potential investors.
The government is now considering further exploration of the block or allocating it to a state-owned company. The unsuccessful auction highlights the challenges India faces in attracting private investment in its critical mineral sector.

item.title: Why Nicolas Maduro’s re-election has triggered protests in Venezuela, criticism abroad
item.description:
Venezuela has erupted in protests following President Nicolas Maduro's re-election. The National Electoral Council declared Maduro the winner with 51% of the vote, but the opposition alleges fraud, citing discrepancies and lack of transparent counting. Maduro, who has held power since 2013, amended the constitution in 2009 to eliminate presidential term limits.
The election comes after years of economic crisis, hyperinflation, and social unrest exacerbated by US sanctions. International reactions have been mixed, with Maduro's allies celebrating the result while other nations, including the US, EU, and several Latin American countries, have expressed concerns about the election's legitimacy and called for investigations.

item.title: Behind Leh flight cancellations: high temperatures, low air density
item.description:
Flight cancellations in Leh, Ladakh, were caused by unusually high temperatures.
Aircraft need specific air density for lift and engine thrust. Higher temperatures make air thinner, reducing lift and engine performance. This requires longer runways and more powerful engines for takeoff.
Leh's high altitude exacerbates this issue, as air is already thinner. Global warming contributes to these extreme temperatures, disrupting air travel and increasing runway requirements. Studies show that warmer temperatures reduce take-off weight capacity and necessitate longer take-off distances.
While aircraft manufacturers strive for improvement, the most effective solution is to mitigate global warming by reducing fossil fuel consumption.

item.title: UP govt proposes strengthening anti-conversion law: why, what are the key changes?
item.description:
Uttar Pradesh has amended its law prohibiting unlawful religious conversion, making it stricter and broader in its application.
The amendment, introduced by the BJP government, aims to protect vulnerable groups like minors, people with disabilities, women, and SC/ST communities. It addresses concerns raised by the Allahabad High Court regarding rampant conversion activities.
The key changes include removing restrictions on who can file an FIR, introducing stringent bail conditions similar to those in terrorism and money laundering cases, and increasing punishments for unlawful conversion.
The amendment broadens the definition of unlawful conversion and includes offences related to forced marriage. It also imposes harsher penalties for conversion financed by foreign or illegal institutions, and for acts involving coercion, force, or threats.

item.title: Why Kamala Harris is having a ‘brat summer’
item.description:
Pop star Charli XCX's tweet declaring "kamala IS brat" has sparked a viral trend, with internet users embracing the "brat summer" aesthetic and celebrating Kamala Harris's relatable and unconventional persona. Harris's campaign has embraced the trend, utilizing XCX's branding and resonating with young voters.
The "brat" image aligns with Harris's playful demeanor and candid public remarks, challenging traditional political norms. The trend gains traction amidst Harris's bid for Presidency, aiming to attract younger demographics in a crucial election.

item.title: Why are Russian athletes ‘banned’ from the 2024 Paris Olympics?
item.description:
The decision to ban Russian and Belarusian athletes from competing under their national flags at the Paris Olympics stems from the IOC's stance that Russia's invasion of Ukraine violated the Olympic Truce. Belarus was implicated for allegedly facilitating Russia's military operations.
The IOC suspended the Russian Olympic Committee due to its claims over Ukrainian sports organizations and its involvement with the "International Friendship Association," deemed a political body violating Olympic neutrality.
Although Russian and Belarusian athletes can participate as "Neutral Athletes," the move sparked debate about the concept of "political neutrality" in sports, particularly as athletes from countries with conflict histories are allowed to compete unhindered.

item.title: Kerala landslide: a look at the extreme weather events in India recently
item.description:
Recent years have witnessed a surge in extreme weather events in India, raising concerns about climate change. These events include devastating floods in Kerala and New Delhi, landslides triggered by heavy rainfall, and cyclones causing widespread damage.
The financial capital, Mumbai, experienced a fatal billboard collapse due to thunderstorms, while Assam state faced severe flooding and landslides during the monsoon season. A glacial lake outburst flood in Sikkim resulted in catastrophic impacts, claiming numerous lives. Earlier events include landslides in Uttarakhand and Kerala causing significant casualties and disruption.

item.title: Explained: The recommendations for equivalence across India’s 69 school boards
item.description:
PARAKH, a standards body under the NCERT, has submitted a report to the Ministry of Education on achieving equivalence between different school boards in India, as mandated by the NEP 2020. The report recommends standards across five categories: administration, curriculum, assessment, inclusiveness, and infrastructure.
Key recommendations include a cumulative Class 12 assessment based on marks from Class 9-12, a credit-based system for grades, and standardized question papers developed by a cadre of professional paper setters. Boards are also advised to incorporate digital literacy, periodic school reviews, and ensure basic infrastructure. PARAKH analyzed 32 boards and will monitor the implementation of its recommendations. Implementation is expected to be a slow process, requiring boards to agree to significant changes.

item.title: Why Israel-Hezbollah conflict is heating up
item.description:
Tensions between Israel and Hezbollah escalated significantly following a rocket strike in the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights that killed 12 children and teenagers. Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, vowed retaliation, and labelled the group as the biggest threat at its borders. Hezbollah denied responsibility but has continued its attacks on Israel, stating it will halt them only if a ceasefire in Gaza is established. The current conflict has seen both sides exchange fire, with Israeli airstrikes targeting Hezbollah areas in Lebanon and Hezbollah firing rockets into Israel.
Although both sides have indicated a desire to avoid a full-scale war, the situation remains volatile. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has warned of a harsh response, while Hezbollah has vowed to defend itself against any Israeli aggression. The outcome of the conflict in Gaza could be a key factor in determining the future trajectory of the situation in Lebanon.

item.title: New paper claims 11.9 lakh excess deaths in India in 2020: What is the debate over Covid deaths?
item.description:
A study published in Science Advances estimated 11.9 lakh excess deaths in India during 2020, the first year of the Covid-19 pandemic. The Indian government vehemently refuted these findings, calling them "grossly misleading" and "methodologically flawed." The government maintains official figures of 1.49 lakh deaths in 2020, a number significantly lower than estimates from various studies, including a WHO global study that indicated 47 lakh excess deaths in India during the pandemic period.
The discrepancy arises partly due to the reliance on estimated data from the Sample Registration Survey (SRS) as opposed to actual counts from the Civil Registration System (CRS). Additionally, the government claims 99% registration of deaths in 2020, leading to a figure lower than previous years, which is disputed by experts.
The Science Advances study used data from the National Family Health Survey (NFHS), facing criticism for its methodology. The issue of accurately quantifying Covid-19 deaths is crucial for health policy and economic planning, but the government has not initiated a comprehensive independent assessment. The upcoming 2026 Census presents an opportunity to collect more reliable data on the pandemic's impact.

item.title: Referring to ED case against Kejriwal, why a Mumbai trial court released an accused in a PMLA case
item.description: The Mumbai Special Court recently released an accused in a money laundering case, citing the Supreme Court's decision to grant bail to Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal. The court ruled that the Enforcement Directorate (ED) lacked sufficient "reasons to believe" to justify the arrest. This echoes the SC's stance on Kejriwal's case, where it emphasized the need for judicial review in arrests and the mandatory disclosure of arrest grounds to the accused. The SC's ruling highlights the need for the ED to adhere to due process and provide justifiable reasons for arrests under the stringent PMLA. This development marks a significant legal victory for accused individuals facing stringent laws and sets a precedent for challenging arbitrary arrests.

item.title: Why some 5-star hotels in New Delhi may have to pay crores to the govt
item.description:
Several five-star hotels in New Delhi, including The Imperial and The Claridges, are challenging the Centre's significant increase in their annual ground rent.
These hotels were originally granted perpetual leases in the early 20th century on a nominal ground rent, with revisions to be calculated based on the land's letting value. The Centre argues that previous rent hikes were ad-hoc and the current increase, based on a formula of 5% of the land value, reflects the actual worth.
The hotels dispute the retrospective application of the new rent, arguing that the next revision was due in 2046. They also criticize the lack of prior warning or explanation for the substantial increase. The Delhi High Court has ordered the Land and Development Office (L&DO) to provide hearings to the hotels before revising the ground rent.

item.title: Criticism for India contingent’s Olympics outfit: How it was chosen, what the designer said
item.description:
The design of India's Olympic uniform sparked debate, with criticism focusing on its perceived lack of connection to Indian traditions and aesthetics. The uniform, created by designer Tarun Tahiliani for Tasva, was chosen through a bidding process that considered both financial and creative aspects.
Tahiliani defended his choices, citing logistical constraints, the need for practical attire suitable for the Paris climate, and a balance of tradition and modernity. He also addressed concerns about the use of digital prints instead of traditional weaves and the absence of visible branding, explaining the time limitations and guidelines imposed by the Indian Olympic Committee (IOC).

item.title: Death in Brazil: What is Oropouche fever?
item.description:
Brazil has reported its first two deaths from Oropouche fever, a viral disease transmitted by midges and mosquitos. The two women, both under 30, had no underlying health conditions.
While Oropouche fever is common in Latin America and the Caribbean, this is the first recorded instance of death from the disease. Cases have also been reported in Italy and Cuba recently, marking the first detections in continental Europe and Cuba, respectively.
Symptoms resemble dengue fever and include fever, headaches, pain, chills, and joint stiffness. The disease typically resolves within a week, with severe cases being rare.
There is currently no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment available for Oropouche fever.

item.title: Why passing Class 9 is a major hurdle for Delhi government school students
item.description:
The Delhi government school system faces a persistent challenge: high failure rates in Class 9. This year, around 36% of students failed, and many subsequently drop out.
Several factors contribute to this situation. The implementation of the Right to Education Act's no-detention policy until Class 8, coupled with increased academic pressure leading up to board exams, creates a stressful transition for students. The shift to more Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs) also emphasizes rote learning over conceptual understanding.
To address this, the government has implemented remedial classes, teacher training, and Mission Buniyaad to strengthen foundational skills. They also aim to trace and provide vocational training to dropouts. Despite these efforts, concerns remain about the quality of education offered through the National Institute of Open School (NIOS), which many struggling students are encouraged to join.

item.title: How educated mothers of young kids can help strengthen their learning journey
item.description: The National Initiative for Proficiency in Reading with Understanding and Numeracy (NIPUN) Bharat Mission aims to ensure foundational literacy and numeracy skills by Grade 3. This is supported by a rise in educational attainment among mothers of young children (ages 4-8). Between 2010 and 2022, the proportion of these mothers with education beyond Grade 5 nearly doubled, with some states, like Kerala, seeing over 70% achieving high school education. This presents a unique opportunity to leverage mothers' education for supporting their children's learning journey. The pandemic, by forcing parental involvement in education, has paved the way for this heightened engagement, with mothers becoming key partners in achieving NIPUN's goals.

item.title: SC to examine acquitted man’s ‘right to be forgotten’: What is the right, and how have courts ruled earlier?
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India is set to examine the "right to be forgotten" in a case challenging a Madras High Court ruling. The Madras High Court ordered the removal of a 2014 rape and cheating case judgment from the legal portal Indian Kanoon, as the acquitted man claimed it hindered his Australian citizenship application.
The concept stems from the European Union's right to erasure, enshrined in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which allows individuals to request removal of their personal data deemed inadequate, irrelevant, or excessive. While India lacks a specific statutory framework outlining the right to be forgotten, the Supreme Court's 2017 Puttaswamy judgment recognized the right to privacy as fundamental, potentially encompassing the right to be forgotten. Justice S.K. Kaul, in a concurring opinion, stated that this right doesn't necessitate obliteration of past information but allows individuals to remove data no longer necessary, relevant, or accurate.
Indian courts have issued conflicting rulings on the matter, highlighting the ongoing debate and lack of clear legal precedent. The Supreme Court's decision will likely clarify the scope of the right to be forgotten in India's legal landscape.

item.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Imran Khan plans to run for Oxford University Chancellor: What is the post?
item.description:
Imran Khan, the former Prime Minister of Pakistan imprisoned in August 2023, intends to run for the position of Chancellor of Oxford University. This largely ceremonial role involves guiding the university and representing it globally.
Khan, a former student of Oxford who captained the university's cricket team, is believed to be following a "public demand" to run for the position. Online elections will be held for the first time, with the successful candidate serving a 10-year term.
Khan must fulfill criteria including exceptional achievements and a commitment to Oxford's academic mission. Other notable past Chancellors include former British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Lord Curzon.

item.title: NASA did not say it found life on Mars but is very excited about the discovery of a rock. Here’s why
item.description:
The Perseverance rover has identified a Martian rock named Cheyava Falls that holds potential signs of ancient microbial life.
The rock contains organic compounds, veins of calcium sulfate, and unique mineral formations that resemble features found in Earth rocks associated with past microbial life. While definitive proof of life is lacking, scientists are excited about the possibility that Cheyava Falls could provide valuable insights into Mars' ancient habitability. The rock sample has been stored by the rover for a future mission to return it to Earth for further analysis. However, delays and cost overruns have pushed back the Mars sample return mission, leaving the scientific community in a holding pattern.

item.title: President Droupadi Murmu appoints new Governors for nine states: All about the post and its procedures
item.description:
The President of India appoints Governors, who represent the Centre in each state. Though envisioned as apolitical figures acting on the advice of state Councils of Ministers, Governors possess significant powers, including assent to bills and determining majority proof in assemblies.
Over time, Governors have come under scrutiny for potentially acting on behalf of the central government, leading to friction with state governments, especially those in opposition.
This tension stems from the lack of a mechanism for holding Governors accountable and the perception of their political appointment. Constitutional experts argue this imbalance creates a potential for abuse of power, undermining the separation of powers between the Centre and states.

item.title: 14 Palestinian groups, including Hamas and Fatah, sign China-brokered deal: Why it matters
item.description:
The political factions Hamas and Fatah, key players in the Palestinian territories, have signed a China-brokered declaration committing to end their division and work towards Palestinian unity. The declaration also calls for an international conference to support this goal and the establishment of an independent Palestinian state with Jerusalem as its capital.
The agreement, witnessed by representatives of 12 other Palestinian groups, signifies a potential shift in the Palestinian political landscape. Historically, Hamas and Fatah have differed in their approaches to peace negotiations and Israel. For instance, Hamas initially advocated for armed resistance against Israel, while Fatah, through the PLO, pursued a path of diplomacy culminating in the Oslo Accords. China's involvement highlights its growing influence in the Middle East and its intention to mediate in the long-standing Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Whether this declaration leads to lasting unity and progress remains to be seen, considering past attempts at reconciliation have faltered.

item.title: What is indexation in calculating LTCG tax? Does the removal of indexation benefit in the Budget mean you will pay more tax?
item.description:
The Union Budget for 2024-25 introduced changes to long-term capital gains (LTCG) taxation, eliminating the indexation benefit for assets like property and gold.
Indexation adjusts the purchase price of an asset for inflation, resulting in a more realistic calculation of capital gains. Removing this benefit, coupled with the reduction of the LTCG tax rate to 12.5%, raised concerns about increased tax liability for long-term investors.
The government has defended the changes, arguing that the net effect would be beneficial for most taxpayers, especially given the higher nominal returns on real estate often exceeding inflation. They also emphasized that rollover benefits remain unchanged, allowing for tax exemption on capital gains reinvested in certain assets.
However, industry players and analysts have expressed concerns about potential consequences such as increased short-term selling in the real estate market and the rise of cash transactions to evade taxes. The absence of grandfathering provisions for past purchases has also been criticized.

item.title: Why Australia has banned mining in one of the world’s largest uranium deposits
item.description:
The Australian government has taken steps to permanently ban uranium mining at the Jabiluka site, a heritage-listed area within Kakadu National Park.
The decision, prompted by the wishes of the Mirarr people, who are the traditional custodians of the land, comes after the discovery of ancient stone tools dating back tens of thousands of years at the site.
The move follows international condemnation of Rio Tinto's destruction of ancient Aboriginal rock shelters in 2020, highlighting the importance of protecting Indigenous heritage sites in Australia. The government will extend Kakadu National Park to encompass Jabiluka, ensuring the area remains free from mining activity.

item.title: How is the rainfall performance during the ongoing monsoon season?
item.description:
The monsoon season in India is currently experiencing uneven rainfall distribution. While central and peninsular regions have received normal or excess rainfall, at least 10 states/UTs continue to face below-normal precipitation.
Although June ended with below-average rainfall, July saw an improvement due to a low pressure system in the Bay of Bengal. This system brought significant surplus rainfall to central and southern peninsular India, but other regions, including northwest, extreme north, east, and northeast India, remain dry.
This uneven pattern poses a threat to Kharif crops, as some regions experience excess rainfall while others face deficits.

item.title: Why inclusion of Gaza’s Tell Umm Amer in the World Heritage Site List matters
item.description:
Tell Umm Amer, an ancient Christian monastery in the Gaza Strip, has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site and placed on the List of World Heritage in Danger.
Founded in the 4th century, the site boasts a rich history with archaeological remnants spanning over four centuries. Recognized as the first monastic community in the Holy Land, it is renowned for its five churches, mosaics, and crypt. However, it has suffered damage due to Israel's ongoing conflict with Gaza.
This UNESCO recognition imposes responsibilities on states, including Israel, to protect the site. The listing also opens avenues for international aid to ensure its protection and potential rehabilitation.

item.title: Government slashes prices for targeted cancer drugs: All you need to know
item.description:
India's Budget 2024-25 announced customs duty exemptions on three targeted cancer drugs: trastuzumab deruxtecan, osimertinib, and durvalumab. These drugs, previously subject to a 10% duty, will now be more accessible and affordable for Indian patients. Trastuzumab deruxtecan, marketed as Enhertu, treats HER-2 receptor-positive cancers. Osimertinib, sold as Tagrisso, is used for lung cancers with epidermal growth factor receptors, while durvalumab, known as Imfinzi, is an immunotherapy treatment for various cancers like lung and bladder.
The decision is expected to significantly reduce financial strain on patients and families, as these drugs, previously costing up to lakhs each, will become more affordable.

item.title: What are puberty blockers and why are they prescribed for transgender and gender-diverse teens?
item.description:
Elon Musk's transgender daughter, Vivian Jenna Wilson, publicly refuted her father's claims that she was influenced into using puberty blockers, describing him as an emotionally distant and narcissistic parent.
Vivian's legal transition in 2022 followed her birth as Xavier in 2004. Puberty blockers, medically prescribed to delay the physical changes of puberty, are a common treatment for transgender and gender-diverse teens experiencing gender dysphoria.
The drugs can help alleviate anxiety and stress associated with physical changes that don't align with their gender identity, providing a space for them to explore their feelings and make informed decisions about their future medical care. Prescribed under medical supervision, these medications are administered through injections or implants and come with potential side effects that require careful monitoring.

item.title: Ship carrying 1.4 million litres of oil sinks near Philippines: How oil spills impact the environment
item.description:
Typhoon Gaemi caused significant damage across Taiwan, the Philippines and China, including sinking the oil tanker MT Terra Nova in Manila Bay. The spill, threatening to become the largest in Philippine history, poses a serious risk to marine life and ecosystems.
Authorities are deploying containment booms and skimmers to mitigate the damage. Oil spills have devastating consequences: they disrupt photosynthesis, poison marine animals, and harm sensitive habitats like coral reefs and mangroves.
The cleanup process is challenging and expensive, with long-term impacts on wildlife populations and local economies. Historical oil spills like Exxon Valdez and Deepwater Horizon highlight the enduring environmental and ecological damage caused by these incidents.

item.title: What are Assam’s Charaideo Moidams, India’s UNESCO’s World Heritage Site?
item.description:
Charaideo Moidams, the royal burial sites of the Ahom dynasty in Assam, have been added to UNESCO's World Heritage Sites list. These tumuli, or earthen mounds, represent a unique funerary practice of the Ahoms, a Tai people who ruled Assam from 1228 to 1826.
Each moidam houses one or more chambers containing the remains of Ahom kings and queens, buried with items for their afterlife, along with servants, livestock, and sometimes even their wives. The height of the mound indicates the person's power and stature.
Charaideo holds particular significance as the Ahoms' first capital city and a sacred site. Its history, burial practices, and architecture distinguish it as a unique cultural and historical treasure. The moidams, often referred to as the "Pyramids of Assam," stand as a testament to the Ahom dynasty's cultural legacy.

item.title: Why AI’s present and future bring some serious environmental concerns
item.description:
Google's latest environment report reveals a 13% increase in emissions, primarily driven by higher electricity consumption in its data centers and supply chains. This trend is expected to worsen as AI adoption increases, with AI queries using significantly more energy than traditional searches.
The energy demands of AI stem from its complex processing, requiring more data sifting, signal generation, and cooling. Data centers, already consuming 1-1.3% of global electricity, are projected to double their share by 2026.
While AI faces criticism for its environmental impact, studies also suggest its potential to reduce emissions through optimizing industrial processes and predicting emissions.

item.title: Kargil Vijay Diwas: How India conquered Kargil’s inclement conditions, 25 years ago
item.description:
The Kargil War, ending on July 26, 1999, was a conflict triggered by Pakistani infiltrators occupying high positions in Kargil, Ladakh. The Indian Army, facing heavy casualties, recaptured the territory after a grueling battle.
The extreme conditions of Kargil, including the extreme cold, thin air, and rugged terrain, posed significant challenges for the Indian forces. Soldiers suffered from altitude sickness, equipment malfunctioned, and mobility was hampered. The Indian Army adapted by implementing acclimatization programs, procuring better equipment, and refining assault tactics, including coordinated artillery strikes. India's victory highlighted the deadly nature of high-altitude combat and the crucial role of adapting to the environment's harsh realities.

item.title: Why Paris Olympics will be the most climate friendly in history
item.description:
Paris 2024 aims to be the greenest Olympics ever, pledging to halve the event's carbon emissions compared to previous Games. Numerous climate-friendly initiatives are in place, including powering the Games with renewable energy, promoting sustainable food choices, prioritizing public transportation, and utilizing existing venues and temporary infrastructure.
The Olympic Village incorporates sustainable materials and aims to convert the new apartments into permanent housing. While organizers plan to offset unavoidable emissions, some experts criticize offsetting as "greenwashing" and emphasize the need for real emission reductions. Despite challenges, Paris 2024 sets a precedent for future sporting events, implementing sustainable practices with lasting benefits for Parisians.

item.title: Why is there a move to split the Bengaluru municipal corporation into smaller bodies with a 3-tier structure?
item.description:
A proposal to restructure the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP), splitting it into smaller city corporations, is being debated in Karnataka. The Greater Bengaluru Governance Bill, 2024, aims to establish a three-tier governance structure with the Greater Bengaluru Authority (GBA) at the top, followed by city corporations and ward committees.
The bill specifies criteria for city corporations based on population, revenue, and employment, aiming for a maximum of ten corporations. The BBMP will likely be divided into five units. The proposal has faced opposition from the BJP, who argue it is unscientific and will harm the city's linguistic identity. The Congress, led by Deputy Chief Minister D K Shivakumar, contends the restructuring is necessary due to the city's rapid and uncontrolled growth. The bill will be discussed further by lawmakers on July 27.

item.title: What is the Hema Commission report, and why has the Kerala HC stayed its release?
item.description:
The Kerala High Court temporarily halted the release of the Justice Hema Commission report, investigating women's experiences in the Malayalam film industry. The report, which surfaced after the 2017 sexual assault of an actress, alleged a casting couch culture and gender inequality within the industry.
Though submitted in 2019, the government delayed its release, citing confidentiality concerns. The Kerala State Information Commission ordered a controlled release, but the release was stayed after a petition argued that it would violate privacy and potentially incite harassment. The court will hear the case further on August 1st.

item.title: The history of Rashtrapati Bhavan’s Durbar Hall and Ashok Hall, now renamed
item.description:
President Droupadi Murmu announced the renaming of two halls in Rashtrapati Bhavan, the 'Durbar Hall' to 'Ganatantra Mandap' and 'Ashok Hall' to 'Ashok Mandap'. The decision aims to reflect Indian cultural values, as 'Durbar' is associated with courts of past rulers.
The Durbar Hall, constructed in 1929, hosts key events like the conferring of honors and swearing-in ceremonies. Its design, influenced by both Western and Indian architectural styles, features high walls, a grand dome, and intricate marble jaalis.
Originally a ballroom, the Ashok Hall, is now used for presenting credentials and formal introductions before state banquets. It features Belgian chandeliers, paintings, hunting scenes, and inscriptions in Persian, reflecting a blend of architectural influences.

item.title: How the modern Olympics came to be
item.description:
The idea to revive the ancient Olympic Games predates Pierre de Coubertin.
