In the 1830s, Greek poet Panagiotis Soutsos invoked the glory of ancient Greece through his poetry, urging for a revival of the Games. Evangelos Zappas, a wealthy Greek benefactor, took up Soutsos' call and funded the first modern Olympic Games in Athens in 1859.
Athens hosted subsequent Games in 1870, 1875, and 1888, with the last held in the newly built Panathenaic Stadium. Meanwhile, in England, W.P Brookes organized the "Annual Wenlock Olympic Games," later the "National Olympic Games" with the aim of promoting international sporting competition. Brookes' vision inspired Coubertin, who in 1894 established the International Olympic Committee. Following Coubertin's initiative, the first International Olympic Games were held in Athens in 1896, marking the beginning of the modern Olympic era.

item.title: ‘Royalty is not a tax’: How Supreme Court recognised states’ powers to tax mining activities
item.description:
The Supreme Court ruled that states can collect royalties from mining leaseholders separately from, and in addition to, taxes on mining activities. This resolves a long-standing dispute triggered by a 1989 decision that deemed royalties as a tax, limiting state revenue.
The nine-judge bench held that royalties are distinct from taxes, based on contractual agreements instead of public purpose funding. This, along with the power granted to states under the Constitution's Seventh Schedule, allows states to levy taxes on land used for mining activities, independent of royalties.

item.title: What to know about the Listeria outbreaks in the US and Canada
item.description:
Two recent outbreaks of listeria, a foodborne bacteria, have been reported in the United States and Canada. The US outbreak, linked to deli meats, has resulted in two deaths and 28 hospitalizations. Listeria infection can cause vomiting, fever, and in severe cases, be fatal, especially for pregnant women, the elderly, and those with compromised immune systems.
In Canada, the outbreak is associated with plant-based refrigerated beverages, prompting recalls of several brands. Symptoms of listeriosis may not appear for up to two months, making it difficult to trace the source of infection.
Both countries are investigating the outbreaks. Health officials advise avoiding unheated deli meats and thoroughly heating any consumed to kill bacteria. Prompt medical attention is recommended for anyone experiencing symptoms.

item.title: US elections 2024: Who might Kamala Harris pick as her Vice Presidential candidate?
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris is considering potential running mates as she prepares for the 2024 Presidential election. Key factors influencing her decision include winning swing states and balancing the ticket with a male candidate. Among the frontrunners are Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro, Arizona Senator Kyrsten Sinema, Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear, Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker, and North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper. Each candidate brings unique strengths and political experience to the table, tailoring their profiles to appeal to different demographics and key battleground states.

item.title: Why the Supreme Court couldn’t agree on environmental release of GM mustard
item.description:
The Supreme Court split on whether to allow the "environmental release" of genetically modified (GM) mustard. Justice Nagarathna ruled against the approval, stating that the Genetic Engineering Appraisal Committee (GEAC) did not sufficiently consider public trust and the precautionary principle. She pointed to a lack of long-term studies and a sudden shift in GEAC's stance.
Justice Karol, in contrast, supported the approval, arguing that field trials were necessary to assess environmental safety and performance. He highlighted the GEAC's independent and reasoned process, including expert committee findings on honeybee impact and recommendations from relevant government departments.
Both judges directed the government to establish a national policy on GM crops, involving experts, farmers, and state governments.

item.title: Why Economic Survey argues for climate adaptation, not mitigation
item.description:
The Indian Economic Survey challenges the current international framework for tackling climate change, arguing that its focus on the 1.5-degree Celsius temperature target is unrealistic and unfairly burdens developing nations.
The Survey highlights the inequities in the system, noting that developed countries, despite having the largest historical responsibility for greenhouse gas emissions, have not fulfilled their commitments to reduce emissions and provide financial and technological assistance to developing nations.
It proposes a shift in emphasis towards adaptation measures, arguing that climate change impacts are already being felt and that rapid development and resilience-building are crucial for vulnerable communities. The Survey also criticizes the scientific community for perpetuating a narrative that ignores the historical context and unequal impacts of climate change.

item.title: Why end of indexation benefit on property sale has ignited a debate
item.description:
The government defended its proposed capital gains tax changes, stating that the new regime without indexation would be beneficial for most individuals due to higher real estate appreciation rates. They acknowledged that the change may impact those with lower returns, less than 9-11% annually, but argued that this scenario is rare.
However, industry experts expressed concerns. They predicted a rise in secondary market real estate sales as individuals seek to avoid holding assets beyond 3-5 years under the new regime. They also suggested a potential increase in cash transactions due to the tax implications.
Real estate experts noted that while the new rate might be advantageous for short-term holdings (3-5 years), it could increase tax burdens for long-term investments with annual appreciation of 10-12%. They also highlighted the disparity in taxation between real estate and equities, advocating for broader tax reform to achieve parity.

item.title: Can the Indian Navy warship INS Brahmaputra sail again? Here’s what we know so far
item.description: The INS Brahmaputra, an indigenously built Indian naval frigate, suffered heavy damage from a fire that broke out while it was undergoing a refit in Mumbai. The fire, which was extinguished with the help of firefighters, caused the ship to list heavily. While the exact cause of the fire is under investigation, potential factors include welding work, electrical short circuits, or ignited oil. The Indian Navy aims to repair the ship and restore its seaworthiness. This incident raises concerns about the safety and maintenance of naval vessels, particularly during refit periods.

item.title: Kathmandu plane crash kills 18: What we know so far, why Nepal has a poor aviation safety record
item.description: A Bombardier CRJ200 aircraft operated by Saurya Airlines crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal on July 24th, killing 18 people. The pilot, Manish Shankya, was the sole survivor and is currently hospitalized. The aircraft was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians bound for Pokhara for maintenance checks. Eyewitness accounts and videos suggest the plane flipped shortly after takeoff, hitting the ground with its wing-tip before catching fire and plunging into a gorge. A climb failure, potentially caused by engine failure, faulty pre-flight planning, technical issues, or pilot error, is suspected to be the cause. This accident highlights Nepal's ongoing challenges with aviation safety, including its mountainous terrain, unpredictable weather, aging aircraft fleet, and inadequate regulation.

item.title: Why July 21 was the warmest day on record, and what may happen in the next few days
item.description:
On July 21st, 2023, the Earth recorded its warmest day ever, reaching an average global temperature of 17.09 degrees Celsius. This surpasses the previous record set just two weeks prior.
The primary cause of this extreme warming is the increased concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, largely due to human activities like burning fossil fuels. Elevated temperatures in Antarctica and reduced sea ice extent are also contributing factors. Scientists predict a further rise in global temperatures with a peak anticipated around July 2024.

item.title: Meta introduces Llama 3.1: What is an open-source AI model? How can it change the world?
item.description:
Meta has unveiled Llama 3.1, its largest open-source AI model to date, claiming it outperforms rivals like OpenAI's GPT-4 and Anthropic's Claude 3.5 on various benchmarks. Llama 3.1 is available in three sizes: 405B, 70B, and 8B, with the largest model surpassing predecessors in complexity and cost-effectiveness.
Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasizes the benefits of open-source AI, citing its transparency, security, and cost advantages. He predicts Meta AI, powered by Llama, will become the most popular AI assistant by the end of the year. Llama 3.1 also features safety mechanisms like Llama Guard to mitigate potential harms.
Zuckerberg views open-source AI as a driver of innovation and accessibility, fostering collaboration and benefiting startups, universities, and developing nations. He believes it has the potential to enhance human productivity, creativity, and overall quality of life.

item.title: Why Big Tech is facing scrutiny over investments in AI research, products
item.description:
Microsoft and Apple have recently stepped back from observer roles on the OpenAI board, amidst increasing scrutiny over Big Tech's involvement in AI. Microsoft, which had invested $10 billion in OpenAI, claimed its observer role was no longer necessary. Apple, while not an investor, was to join the board as part of a partnership to integrate ChatGPT into its operating systems. This decision comes as regulatory bodies like the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and European Union (EU) are investigating the competitive landscape of AI, particularly concerning partnerships and investments between Big Tech and AI research companies.
Concerns arise from Big Tech's influence on AI development, as they provide crucial resources like data, computing power, and funding. Critics argue this concentration of power could stifle innovation and lead to monopolies, hindering the potential of open and diverse AI research.

item.title: Explained: Panchamasali Lingayats, and politics surrounding their quota demands
item.description:
The Panchamasali Lingayats, a significant sub-caste within Karnataka's dominant Lingayat community, are demanding inclusion in Category 2A of the Other Backward Classes (OBC) reservation system. This would provide them with access to a 15% quota in government jobs and college admissions, unlike the current 5% quota they receive under Category 3B.
Their agitation stems from a perceived lack of political representation and economic disadvantage despite their large population. Previous attempts to address their concerns, including the allocation of a larger quota to Lingayats as a whole, have failed to satisfy the Panchamasalis.
The issue has become politically sensitive, influencing the outcome of the 2023 Karnataka elections. The Congress party, which won the elections, is now tasked with finding a solution that balances the interests of various OBC groups and placates the Panchamasalis.

item.title: Explained: Making sense of the 2024-25 Union Budget
item.description:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman's 2024-25 Budget marks a significant departure from previous budgets. It acknowledges the current economic distress in India, despite relatively encouraging GDP growth numbers.
The budget prioritizes agriculture, focusing on boosting farm research, pulses, and oilseed production, and natural farming. To address job creation and skill gaps, the government is shifting from Production-linked Incentives (PLI) towards Employment-linked Incentives (ELI). The focus on small and medium enterprises (SMEs), which have been struggling, is another key element.
Recognizing the need for collaborative governance, the budget emphasizes working with states to implement reforms and develop industrial parks. The government aims to create a new economic policy framework that facilitates employment and sustains high growth.

item.title: The rise of Kamala Harris, and what her likely presidential nomination signifies
item.description:
US President Joe Biden announced his withdrawal from the 2024 presidential race, endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris as his successor. Harris, who would become the first woman and the first person of South Asian and Black heritage to be nominated for president by a major party, has inherent advantages due to her position, age, and diverse background. While her potential nomination is historic and reflects the changing demographics of the US, Harris faces challenges, including criticism for her past handling of certain legal issues and the need to demonstrate effectiveness in addressing issues like immigration.
Recent polls indicate a tight race against the Republican candidate, highlighting the complexities and uncertainties surrounding the upcoming election.

item.title: Why has SC stayed police notice asking dhaba owners on Kanwar Yatra route to disclose their names?
item.description:
The Supreme Court has blocked police orders in Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and Madhya Pradesh requiring businesses along the Kanwar Yatra route to display the names of their owners and employees. The court found these directions lacked legal foundation and could be issued under existing food safety or street vendor laws.
While the court didn't address the petitioners' arguments that the orders discriminated against Muslim-owned businesses, it highlighted concerns about the violation of privacy rights guaranteed under Article 21 of the Constitution. The judgement also noted potential violations of the right to practice any profession, as claimed by petitioners who argued the orders could lead to economic boycotts targeting specific religious or caste groups.

item.title: Budget 2024: Bihar’s Vishnupad and Mahabodhi temples, for which corridor projects were announced
item.description: Nirmala Sitharaman announced the construction of model corridor projects at the Vishnupad and Mahabodhi Temple in Bihar, inspired by the successful Kashi Vishwanath Temple Corridor project. The Vishnupad Temple, dedicated to Lord Vishnu, holds religious significance for Hindus, particularly during pitra paksh. The Mahabodhi Temple Complex at Bodh Gaya, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is the location where Gautam Buddha attained nirvana. Development of infrastructure and public amenities at these sites is anticipated to enhance their appeal as pilgrim and tourist destinations.

item.title: What is a climate finance taxonomy, announced by FM Sitharaman?
item.description:
India will develop a 'climate finance taxonomy' to boost capital for climate adaptation and mitigation. Taxonomies classify economic activities as sustainable investments, guiding capital towards climate action and reducing greenwashing.
India's green finance flows are insufficient, accounting for only 3% of total FDI. A taxonomy will clarify sustainable investments, potentially attracting more international climate funds. With a $3.1 trillion climate-smart investment potential, India aims to electrify vehicles and achieve 50% non-fossil fuel-based energy by 2030.

item.title: New Tax Regime tweaked: How taxpayers can save up to Rs 17,500 a year in income tax
item.description:
The Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, announced an increase in the standard deduction to Rs 75,000 from Rs 50,000, and made minor adjustments to the tax slabs under the New Tax Regime (NTR). This results in a maximum tax benefit of Rs 17,500 per year for individual taxpayers under the NTR.
The highest tax bracket, those with taxable income of Rs 15 lakh or more, will see the most significant benefit, saving Rs 7,500 due to the increased standard deduction and an additional Rs 10,000 from rate rationalization.
The government has widened the tax base and aims for a simple income tax regime by potentially encouraging more taxpayers to adopt the NTR. Survey data suggests this effort is working, with 70% of taxpayers opting for the NTR.
Changes made to the NTR bring the tax outgo closer to the Old Tax Regime after accounting for all deductions, making it more attractive to potential users.
